elizabeth veldon.title: i changed my sex
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
things are grim for trans, non binary and intersex people just now and i wanted to express that.
this isn't just in the usa, here in the uk the health secretary has met with and expressed support for a group that advises parents of trans children to abuse them, more and more doctors are refusing to dispense existing prescriptions for hrt and a far right party is ahead in the polls.
the title of this comes from the autobiography of the trans stripper heady jo star (see meyerowitz's 'how sex changed: a history of transsexuality in the united states' published by harvard university press, 2002.)

trackinfo.title: i changed my sex
trackinfo.label: black circle records
trackinfo.credits: from i changed my sex, released February 7, 2025

elizabeth veldon.title: i_consume_ it_consumes_us (practice sessions and live)
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
there tracks where composed for an event discussing consumerism and repetition held across mono and stereo in glasgow.
the live recording of the second track was unusable so has been recreated.
both tracks are based around the word 'repetition'
the second track was performed using a strict ritual:
1. each note represents one of the letters in the word 'repetition' and the keys are held down with masking tape
2. each two minutes a new key is pressed or released (in the second half of the piece)
3. one minute after each key was pressed the position of the second key was determined using a set formula
4. at 1.40 a small section of masking tape was ripped off, on 1.50 a length ripped off
5. at 1.55 this was placed on the key and the key pressed and secured at 2.00

trackinfo.label: black circle records
trackinfo.credits: from i_consume_ it_consumes_us (practice sessions and live), released September 1, 2013

elizabeth veldon.title: 'i learned that the death of each victim carries importance, i want to convey that'
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this album was inspired by an article about a doctoral student in japan who researched the experiences of taxi drivers in Ishinomaki, Miyagi Prefecture when they picked up ghosts of young people killed in the 2011 tsunami.
titles are taken from the article which is included in the download as a text document
all tracks are unedited improvisations

trackinfo.title: the woman directed him, 'please go to the minamihama (district).' the driver, in his 50s, asked her, 'the area is almost empty. is it ok?' then, the woman said in a shivering voice, 'have i died?'

elizabeth veldon.title: i make this song about myself (revisiting cuidus contrarium verum est)
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this album revisits the incomplete christine the astonishing work and allows a sort of closure on something that was rather abruptly abandoned.
the title comes from the first line of the anglo saxon poem 'the wife's lament.'
I make this song of myself, deeply sorrowing,
my own life’s journey. I am able to tell
all the hardships I’ve suffered since I grew up,
but new or old, never worse than now –
ever I suffer the torment of my exile.
arts.uwaterloo.ca/~rtierney/TheWifesLament.pdf

elizabeth veldon.title: i saw the wizard of west bow astride a headless horse as i assended to victoria street
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this is a reworking of a piece i did in 2016 which i was always unhappy with.
it concerns the life and particularly the afterlife of a noted edinburgh resident who was claimed to be sited upon a headless horse after his death.
I'm moving to edinburgh in just under a month and thought it was time to revisit this piece.
included in the download is a newspaper piece about 'the wizard of west bow' and the cover uses the same image as the origional release.
i liked the other track on the original album which concerned itself with 'the gurning man of crosshill.' this can be found here:  elizabethveldon.bandcamp.com/track/the-gurning-man-of-crosshill

elizabeth veldon.title: i woke - i did, indeed - a million years before the blooming sun
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this track came to me last night when i stumbled out of bed at 2.30am to feed the cat and i saw the still bright sky.
it is based upon a note in jon stallworthy's (ed.) two volume edition of the works of wilfred owen and relates to the poem 'futility'
stallworthy finds a source for the image of the sun '[waking] ...the clays of a cold star' in john davidson's 'thirty bob a week'
elizabeth veldon.credits:
released June 11, 2015
instruments: celviano ap 245 and ableton live

elizabeth veldon.title: if we are ever alone: three nights of darkness for easter 2021 (night 1)
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this release is an attempt to represent the three nights of tenebrae using the length of each night as the duration of the piece.
the tenebrae is the ritualistic stripping of the alter for three days before easter sunday and is latin for 'darkness.'
these three pieces should not be understood as individual works but as a unified whole.

elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this is the final part of my tenebrae trilogy and ends with down on easter sunday.
but the angel said to the women, 'do not be afraid : i know that you are looking for jesus who was crucified. he is not here; for he has been raised, as he said. come see the place where he lay. then go quickly and tell his disciples 'he has been raised from the dead,' and indeed he is going ahead of you into galilee; there you will see him.' this is my message for you.'
matthew 28: 5-7

elizabeth veldon.title: if we shadows have offended think on this and all is mended
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this is an extended reworking of a track for the 'button box' album on linear obsession. the 'shadows' are the sounds that a harmonium makes between the notes and the title is a reference to puck's final speech in 'a midsummer night's dream'
if we shadows have offended,
think but this, and all is mended,
that you have but slumber’d here
while these visions did appear.
and this weak and idle theme,
no more yielding but a dream,
gentles, do not reprehend:
if you pardon, we will mend.
and, as i’m an honest puck,
if we have unearned luck
now to ’scape the serpent’s tongue,
we will make amends ere long;
else the puck a liar call:
so, good night unto you all.
give me your hands, if we be friends,
and robin shall restore amends.
a midsummer night's dream act 5, scene 2
elizabeth veldon.credits:
released February 16, 2015
cover from:
after sir joshua reynolds 1723–1792 'puck or robin goodfellow'

trackinfo.title: if we shadows have offended think on this and all is mended
trackinfo.label: black circle records
trackinfo.credits: from if we shadows have offended think on this and all is mended, released February 16, 2015

elizabeth veldon.title: i'm not afraid any more
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this album is for all those who live in fear. that may be from an abusive partner, a toxic family, from people they think are more powerful than them.
if you do not give them your fear you can begin to move beyond them.
i'm not afraid any more
the album can be downloaded from cybercrud, a new queer and poc focused net label:  cybercrud.bandcamp.com/album/im-not-afraid-anymore

elizabeth veldon.title: (in her eyes) space is curved and it is possible to have a straight line
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
text by Nicolas Grenier, sounds by elizabeth Veldon
(in her eyes) space is curved and it is possible to have a straight line
A pinkish tear falls from a moon
Lean girl
It is nighttime painted in gold
In the morning
On the lawn
Open letter of April 25 to the wing of an angel
L for joy
Unknown (y)ears
At the poles
Your cherry-navel
Like a monogrammed glove
On my cloudy hair
For a while
Behind the blinds
You pray to the Lord
Everytime you blink
I dive into a dazzling light

elizabeth veldon.about:
like 'but she's become a fish again' this album was born out of an examination of the supernatural in folk ballads.
this is based upon the irish ballad 'she moved through the fair'
last night she came to me, my dead love came in
so softly she came that her feet made no din
as she laid her hand on me and this she did say:
it will not be long, love, 'til our wedding day.

elizabeth veldon.title: jamie foyers' dream of the rood
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this is the second in a series exploring early english language poetry.
this is based upon the great anglo-saxon poem 'the dream of the rood' and ewan maccoll's great song 'jamie foyers'
though separated by a considerable length of time, subject matter and poetic meter both works are elegiac in their different ways.

elizabeth veldon.title: jenny wi’ the iron teeth
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
'jenny' is a far more illusive character than the gorbals vampire and is often mentioned as part of the cultural mix that led to her more famous offspring but she deserves attention on her own.
jenny wi- the iron teeth dates from the late 19th and early 20th century when it was believed a monster haunted glasgow green and lived in a shed owned by two elderly women (possibly called 'Allen' one of whom had substandard dental work carried out leaving iron fillings in her teeth clearly visible.
included with the download is a fairly famous poem about this urban legend
the cover features the engraving '“Glasgow from the Green”, 1828' by E. Francis, taken from a drawing by W. Westfall
this is the second of four halloween albums

trackinfo.credits: from jenny wi’ the iron teeth, released September 25, 2020

elizabeth veldon.title: Lowland Islands 1 (Greater Cumbrea)
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
The album "Lowland Islands. 1 (Greater Cumbrea)" is a sonic interpretation of the islands in the Clyde river estuary, Scotland. Building on a prolific back-catalogue, elizabeth Veldon utilises structured harmonics, minimalist drones and alternating scales to represent Kilchatten Bay & Fintray Bay on the west coast of Scotland.
These drones express an isolation from the mainland, a barrenness and also the fragility of being a passing soul through a timeless landscape. There is a bleak sense of otherwordliness when you listen to these drones - almost alienation.
At ease with her equipment, she deftly employed the use of physical, analogue technologies and software instruments to build this minimalist composition in to a timeless reminder that we are but fleeting effigies.
elizabeth Veldon is a sound artist working primarily in the areas of long form drone, minimalism and improvisation.
This is the first album in a three-part series that explores the artist's relationship with isolated areas - figuratively and literally.
elizabeth veldon.credits:
released November 1, 2016
© elizabeth Veldon
Artwork © Andrew Backhouse
www.focusedsilence.com

elizabeth veldon.title: mary's song
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this will be my final christmas album and in the year that i rediscovered my faith i have chosen to represent mary's song (luke 1: 46-55)
And Mary[a] said,
“My soul magnifies the Lord,
and my spirit rejoices in God my Savior,
for he has looked with favor on the lowliness of his servant.
Surely, from now on all generations will call me blessed;
for the Mighty One has done great things for me,
and holy is his name.
His mercy is for those who fear him
from generation to generation.
He has shown strength with his arm;
he has scattered the proud in the thoughts of their hearts.
He has brought down the powerful from their thrones,
and lifted up the lowly;
he has filled the hungry with good things,
and sent the rich away empty.
He has helped his servant Israel,
in remembrance of his mercy,
according to the promise he made to our ancestors,
to Abraham and to his descendants forever.”
Cover image from the book of kells

he never came out of the cave system but his dog and - blind and without any hair on it's body.

elizabeth veldon.title: my language comes and goes
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this album was written for a friend who found they couldn't write when they where ill and has sat, waiting to be edited into a publishable format, for over a month.
Since then there has been a sudden change in the law in the uk which makes life intensely more difficult for trans people like myself and the person this album was written for. This change has stripped trans people of many of the rights they have enjoyed for fifteen years or more and will be tested legally by the good law project who are building a legal fund to fight it.
This album is a fund raiser for that and will be met with further fun raisers for trans orgs in the coming week or two.
If you can't afford the £5 then donate what you can to the good law project, provide me with a screenshot and I'll send you a download code.
All money from this will go to fund legal action.
lex iniusta non est lex (an unjust law is no law at all)

elizabeth veldon.title: notes towards 'westron wynd'
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this album concerns itself with the medieval fragment 'westron wynd.'
these four lines inspired three tudor masses and have resonated down the years to our own time where they still provide inspiration for writers and musicians.
in this album i have taken two themes and two elements of the poem and constructed two hour pieces for both. these represent (on one level) four of the five elements of 'the english mass' and the four parts of the mass set by the earliest use of this poem in a mass setting in tallis' 'Mass: Western Wynd.'
the final section of the mass will be realised, should the opportunity arise, be creating a four channel installation from this in a building of suitable antiquity. the final part of the mass and the cantus firmus (that is the key text) of this final realisation would be an emergent property of the installation and the experience of the individual experiencing it.
this, however, is not only an abstract mass setting but is also an exploration of the poem and medieval symbolic systems that allowed multiple readings of a (not always religious) text to coexist and inform each other. in this instance this can be seen as being an exploration of a poem, an abstract mass setting and an exploration of the religious meaning often given to secular works in the medieval world (here the loneliness of the speaker would be seen as symbolising the desire of the soul to be unified with god in heaven.)
this is just the first form of this piece and i hope to be able to complete it with a staging in the fairly near future.
Westron wynd, when wylle thow blow,
The smalle rayne down can rayne?
Cryst, yf my love were in my Armys
And I yn my bed a gayne!
This piece has necessitated a little research and the books and other media i have used are as follows:
Ferguson, Salter and Stallworthy (ed) 'The Norton Anthology of Poetry.' Norton (fifth edition)
Rothenberg, D. J., 'The Flower Of Paradise: Marian Devotion and Secular Song in Medieval and Renaissance Europe.' Oxford University Press.
Butterfield, A., 'Venacular Poetry and Music' and Lefferts, P. M., 'England.' in Everist, M. (ed.) The Cambridge Companion to Medieval Music.' Cambridge University Press.
'The Early Music Show: The Western Wind.' BBC Radio Four.
The Sixteen with Christophers, 'Mass: Western Wynd.' Helios.

elizabeth veldon.title: nowel, nowel, nowel
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
the pieces in this album come from the trinity carol roll:  en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trinity_Carol_Roll
Nowel, nowel, nowel
Nowel, nowel, nowel
To us is born owr god Emanuel.
In bedlem this berde of lyf
Is born of marye maydyn and wyf
He is bothe god and man i-schryf
Nowel, nowel.
Thys prince of pees shal secyn al stryf
And wone wyth us perpetuel.
Nowel, nowel...
This chyld shal bey us wyth hys bloyd
And be naylyd upon the royd
Hys raunsom pasyth al erdly goyd
Nowel, nowel
Allas qwat wyth dar be so woyd
To sle so ientyl a iowel.
Nowel, nowel...
Be hys powste he hys emprys
Schal take fro helle at hys uprys
And save mankende upon this wys
Nowel, nowel
Thus telly us the prophecys
That he is kyng of heven and helle.
Nowel, nowel...
This maydenys sone to hys empere
Schal stey to hevene be his powere
Hys holy gost us alle shal lere
Nowel, nowel
[They and] the fadyr in feere
Schal rengne o God this leve I weel.
Nowel, nowel...
Prey we this chyld wyth good entent
In our deying he is present
Onto hys fadyr omnypotent
Nowel, nowel
The ferst tydyng of this testament
Browth to us seynt Gabryel.
Nowel, nowel...
Nowel syng we now al and sum
Nowel syng we now al and sum
For rex pacificus is cum.
In Bedleem in that fayr cite
A child was born of a maydyn fre
That shal a lord and prynce be
A solis ortus cardine.
Nowel syng we...
Childryn were slayn ful greth plente
Ihesu for the love of the
Qwerfore here sowlys savyd be.
Hostis Herodis impie.
Nowel syng we...
As sunne schynyth thorw the glas
So Ihesu in hys modyr was
The to serve now graunth us gras.
O lux beata trinitas.
Nowel syng we...
Now God is comyn to wurchepyn us
Now of Marye is born Ihesus
Make we mery amongys us.
Exultet celum laudibus.
Nowel syng we...

elizabeth veldon.title: o my hart (holocaust remembrance day 2021)
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this is a piano improvisation for holocaust remembrance day based on henry the 8th's 'o my hart'
O my hart and O my hart!
My hart it is so sore,
Sens I must nedys from my love depart
And know no cunse wherefore.
this piece utilises a technique for scoring for the piano where i choose a key at random to act as a 'home' key then take this as representing the letter 'a.' each subsequent letter i wish to transcribe (in this case 'o my hart') is taken from this point where each key moving right from this point represents another letter in the sequence of the alphabet (1=a, 2=b...) These notes then form the basis of an improvisation. in this piece additional notes are introduced in each movement to pull the composition further to the right of the keyboard, and to produce a deeper, richer texture. the symbolic nature of this i allow you to decide.
for this piece i used a software piano and controller as my piano is in storage.

trackinfo.label: black circle records
trackinfo.credits: from o my hart (holocaust remembrance day 2021), released January 27, 2021

trackinfo.title: call the robin red breast and the wren
trackinfo.label: black circle records
trackinfo.about:
Call for the robin-redbreast and the wren,
Since o'er shady groves they hover
And with leaves and flowers do cover
The friendless bodies of unburied men.
Call unto his funeral dole
The ant, the field-mouse, and the mole,
To rear him hillocks that shall keep him warm
And, when gay tombs are robb'd, sustain no harm;
But keep the wolf far thence, that's foe to men,
For with his nails he'll dig them up again.
John Webster, The White Devil.
trackinfo.credits: from O swallow swallow/ Le Prince d’Aquitaine à la tour abolie, released September 15, 2011

trackinfo.title: When shall I see the white-thorn leaves agen
trackinfo.label: black circle records
trackinfo.about:
the yellowhammer
When shall I see the white-thorn leaves agen,
And yellowhammers gathering the dry bents
By the dyke side, on stilly moor or fen,
Feathered with love and nature's good intents?
Rude is the tent this architect invents,
Rural the place, with cart ruts by dyke side.
Dead grass, horse hair, and downy-headed bents
Tied to dead thistles--she doth well provide,
Close to a hill of ants where cowslips bloom
And shed oer meadows far their sweet perfume.
In early spring, when winds blow chilly cold,
The yellowhammer, trailing grass, will come
To fix a place and choose an early home,
With yellow breast and head of solid gold.
-john clare
trackinfo.credits: from O swallow swallow/ Le Prince d’Aquitaine à la tour abolie, released September 15, 2011

elizabeth veldon.title: o wind, forgi’e a hameless loon that canna see for tears!
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
based on Violet Jacob's 'the wild geese' and in answer to the desire to see burns as the greatest scottish poet.
'Oh tell me what was on yer road, ye roarin’ norlan’ Wind,
As ye cam’ blawin’ frae the land that’s niver frae my mind?
My feet they traivel England, but I’m deein’ for the north.'
'My man, I heard the siller tides rin up the Firth o Forth.'
'Aye, Wind, I ken them weel eneuch, and fine they fa’ and rise,
And fain I’d feel the creepin’ mist on yonder shore that lies,
But tell me, ere ye passed them by, what saw ye on the way?'
'My man, I rocked the rovin’ gulls that sail abune the Tay.'
'But saw ye naething, leein’ Wind, afore ye cam’ to Fife?
There’s muckle lyin’ ‘yont the Tay that’s mair to me nor life.'
'My man, I swept the Angus braes ye hae'na trod for years.'
'O Wind, forgi’e a hameless loon that canna see for tears!'
'And far abune the Angus straths I saw the wild geese flee,
A lang, lang skein o’ beatin’ wings, wi’ their heids towards the sea,
And aye their cryin’ voices trailed ahint them on the air –'
'O Wind, hae maircy, haud yer whisht, for I daurna listen mair!'

elizabeth veldon.title: on a winter's night watching the armaments factory you can hear the pig latin of centurions complaining of the cold
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
during ww2 soldiers where stationed in murdoch castle, a 13th century fortification now incorporated into murdoch county park, to guard the clydebank armaments factories, fuel dumps and the local reservoir.
within a mile or two of this stands the antonine wall which was the furthest north the romans managed in scotland.
this seeks to unite the experience of both soldiers and perhaps allow their ghosts to meet on a cold winter night.
this was partly inspired by the following houseman poem:
On Wenlock Edge
On Wenlock Edge the wood's in trouble;
His forest fleece the Wrekin heaves;
The gale, it plies the saplings double,
And thick on Severn snow the leaves.
'Twould blow like this through holt and hanger
When Uricon the city stood:
'Tis the old wind in the old anger,
But then it threshed another wood.
Then, 'twas before my time, the Roman
At yonder heaving hill would stare:
The blood that warms an English yeoman,
The thoughts that hurt him, they were there.
There, like the wind through woods in riot,
Through him the gale of life blew high;
The tree of man was never quiet:
Then 'twas the Roman, now 'tis I.
The gale, it plies the saplings double,
It blows so hard, 'twill soon be gone:
To-day the Roman and his trouble
Are ashes under Uricon.
A.E. Housman
the cover is a section of the antonine wall

elizabeth veldon.title: on margate sands i can connect nothing with nothing
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this is an attempt to represent ts eliot's poem 'the waste land' in an abstract form that keeps the formal structure intact but removes the overt homophobia, anti-semitism, racism and references to eugenics.
each individual speaker or literary reference is assigned a sine wave and each line of the poem has been given two seconds.

elizabeth veldon.title: on passing the new menim gate/ on crossing the drumochter pass
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
i was thinking of both sassoon's famous poem this evening and also missing my partner who is in inverness overnight.
On Passing the New Menin Gate, by Siegfried Sassoon
Who will remember, passing through this Gate,
The unheroic Dead who fed the guns?
Who shall absolve the foulness of their fate, -
Those doomed, conscripted, unvictorious ones?
Crudely renewed, the Salient holds its own.
Paid are its dim defenders by this pomp;
Paid, with a pile of peace-complacent stone,
The armies who endured that sullen swamp.
Here was the world's worst wound. And here with pride
'Their name liveth for evermore' the Gateway claims.
Was ever an immolation so belied
As these intolerably nameless names?
Well might the Dead who struggled in the slime
Rise and deride this sepulchre of crime.

trackinfo.label: black circle records

elizabeth veldon.title: one million dead epistemologies
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this album came about through an interaction with the composer Alex Temple on language that had passed out of common usage in the trans community.
this led me to think about my own experience in the light of justice epistemology.
Thaky you to Alex for her often though provoking contributions to my life.
the text of the facebook post explaining this is included here:
Recently, in conversation with Alex Temple, i was talking about being an elder in the trans community. More truthfully i was realising that in speaking about ‘older trans folks’ when i ‘transitioned’ had led me to realise that i was now one of those older trans folks.
This has led me to ask quite a few questions of myself and my relationship to younger trans folks and ask if i am as eager to force them into a relationship with their bodies and identities which matches my own. I hope i am not and that i do not do this and can find no real trace of this in my actions but there is a kink in this and it is that there are aspects of the experience of younger trans folks, particularly trans femmes, which i find it difficult to share.
I find, among the community, a less fraught relationship to the body and to sex than my generation had. This has led me to question my own experience of dysphoria and my relationship to my pre-surgical body.
The field of social epistemology studies the ways in which knowledge and ways of knowing are formed within groups and i have been thinking about this in relation to how we (we being my generation of trans people) experienced dysphoria and experienced our bodies. To what extent was our experience, our way of knowing our own transness, shaped by group experience and by testimonial injustice towards those who had a different experience?
Testimonial injustice is a form of epistemological injustice whereby we do not give weight to the testimony of those who fall outside our own epistemological group or world view. Though we sought to bring all views within our activism where we suffering the same lack of understanding which (to use a classic case of testimonial injustice) the academy suffered in regards to both feminism and black studies? Where we essentially unable to spot our own epistemology bias and am i only now becoming aware of my own?
Did we make others suffer Hermeneutical injustice (a form of epistemological injustice where the degree of injustice is so great that existing becomes impossible and epistemologies are killed before they are even born - where people are killed) and did we cause ourselves to suffer Hermeneutical injustice?
I know how i felt about my pre-surgical body and l do not regret surgery but would that have been different with a different epistemology? Would that have been different if I was ‘transitioning’ now?
Additionally I have added a blog post discussing the murder of Brianna Ghey which I think is relevent to this, it is part of the download.

sections as follows:

3. we saw oceanus for the first time
4. the land of the dead

for this he received a four year sentence which works out at roughly six minutes and six seconds for each human soul.
the download includes a pdf of a newspaper story from the guardian.

this album was inspired by the nasa image of earth hanging in the evening sky of mars and seeks to tell the story of three generations of mrs colonists from those who first went, their children who are told to remember earth and second generation colonists.

elizabeth veldon.title: overnight sleeper from inverness to london 1/11/2019 (part 1)
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this is the first part of an unedited seven hour recording of a journey i undertook.
i considered scrubbing the recording to remove any sounds i made from it but decided to keep it as it is.
the recording is split into tracks where there is a break or change in the sound of the train (a movement, if you want to call it that) or when it was getting too long to upload to bandcamp.
it begins with me beginning the recording then getting into bed and ends with me getting up and turning it off about an hour and a half outside london

elizabeth veldon.title: passing over in silence
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
i wish to end my relationship with mary midgley in a formal way.
she is simply wrong in so many of her propositions, she is mean spirited and nasty, she lacks the ability to understand metaphor and she lies constantly
all sounds created by ripping a copy of 'the myths we live by', attacking it with scissors, ripping out pages and using a knife to cut pages.
all cut-ups where created from pages cut out of the book.
all titles are taken from wittgenstein's 'tractatus logico-philosophicus'
this mission is terminated.

elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:

this led me to remember jarman's command from the film 'Blue:'
'his world had forgotten the command of essence: Thou Shall Not Create Unto Thyself Any Graven Image, although you know the task is to fill the empty page. From the bottom of your heart, pray to be released from image.'

elizabeth veldon.about:
this is the audio of the three screen installation i worked on last winter.

the download comes with a visitor's guide for the exhibition, a guide for exhibitors, pictures documenting the filming process and links to view unlisted uploads of the three films.
if you want a copy of my write up for a more detailed breakdown of the rational behind this then send me an email and i'll forward it to you.

elizabeth veldon.title: several reflections on anglo-saxon burial rituals for outcasts
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this album came from the left over bits and pieces from my research for the anglo-saxon eps.
what struck me about the burial rituals for outcasts and the myths of their walking after death was it's similarity to rites and myths still prevalent in rural areas of eastern europe until the 19th century.
as with the anglo-saxon eps this proves the fallacy of our great, square jawed ancestors put forward by british nationalist groups.
you can also ignore these notes and just enjoy the music.

elizabeth veldon.title: shine through the gloom and point me to the skies
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this is the final part of a trilogy of works based around the great anglican hymn 'abide with me'
this began as a single piece but i couldn't leave the song alone until i had worked at it for a few days.
i have always taken great comfort from this song and i believe that it's fine words transcend religious belief itself and touch something truly human in us all
Abide with me; fast falls the eventide;
The darkness deepens; Lord with me abide.
When other helpers fail and comforts flee,
Help of the helpless, O abide with me.
Swift to its close ebbs out life's little day;
Earth's joys grow dim; its glories pass away;
Change and decay in all around I see;
O Thou who changest not, abide with me.
Not a brief glance I beg, a passing word,
But as Thou dwell'st with Thy disciples, Lord,
Familiar, condescending, patient, free.
Come not to sojourn, but abide with me.
Thou on my head in early youth didst smile,
And though rebellious and perverse meanwhile,
Thou hast not left me, oft as I left Thee.
On to the close, O Lord, abide with me.
I need Thy presence every passing hour.
What but Thy grace can foil the tempter's power?
Who, like Thyself, my guide and stay can be?
Through cloud and sunshine, Lord, abide with me.
I fear no foe, with Thee at hand to bless;
Ills have no weight, and tears no bitterness.
Where is death's sting? Where, grave, thy victory?
I triumph still, if Thou abide with me.
Hold Thou Thy cross before my closing eyes;
Shine through the gloom and point me to the skies.
Heaven's morning breaks, and earth's vain shadows flee;
In life, in death, O Lord, abide with me.
words: henry francis lyte

elizabeth veldon.title: sleepy songs for leon
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
Come unto these yellow sands,
And then take hands:
Curtsied when you have, and kiss'd
The wild waves whist,
Foot it featly here and there;
And, sweet sprites, the burthen bear.
Hark, hark!
Bow-wow.
The watch-dogs bark.
Bow-wow.
Hark, hark! I hear
The strain of strutting chanticleer
Cry, Cock-a-diddle-dow.
Full fathom five thy father lies;
Of his bones are coral made;
Those are pearls that were his eyes:
Nothing of him that doth fade,
But doth suffer a sea-change
Into something rich and strange.
Sea-nymphs hourly ring his knell:
Ding-dong.
Hark! now I hear them—Ding-dong, bell.

elizabeth veldon.title: snow comes off the hills
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
walking to strathblane and blainfield this week i was reminded of the stories a taxi driver from the area told i and my partner of snow coming off the hills and cutting the whole area off for weeks at a time in severe winters.
both villages literally back onto the campsie fells to such an extent that the streets at the north end of both villages often terminate at the point where the gradient becomes to steep to build on.

elizabeth veldon.about:
this album collects together collaborations on the no longer operative 'black circle records' label i once ran
these tracks span several years of my progression as an artist but are not arranged chronologically
1. from a floppy release

elizabeth veldon.title: some meditations on the transformitive nature of giving (for christina rossetti)
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
in his classic album 'the new possibility' john fahey references the work of the theologian paul tillich and the idea of reawakening 'the new possibility' opend up by the story of christ's birth in luke's gospel: 'The birth of this New Possibility,' he writes, 'has nothing to do with Christmas trees, presents, Santa Claus, and little to do with superstitious thoughts regarding virgin births, astrologers, bodily ascensions of virgins, etc. The New Possibility is rather the gift of reconciliation between God and man. He is for all men at all times and places.'
this strikes me whenever i hear over the top renditions of the carol 'in the bleak midwinter' (words by christinia rossetti) which is about the transformative and redemptive power of giving, of forsaking that which we have for others and the importance of even the smallest, lest ostentatious gift.
this album seeks to reclaim the spiritual importance of the act of giving (either gifts or one's whole self) to others from the commercialisation of this most important and human of acts.
in a way this is a secular realisation of fahey's 'new possibility' - not of a connection with go but with each other.
give because in giving we grow and, as fahey said in the sleeve notes to the new possibility 'Nevertheless, let us do celebrate and rejoice (in proper fashion) the New Possibility; and let us do so with music among other things.'
elizabeth veldon.credits:
released December 21, 2014
on this album i used a waldorf rocket paired with a novation mininova, garageband with a m-audio keystation 61es, allen and heath zed sixty 10fx, moto microbook, macbook pro and a casio celviano ap-245

elizabeth veldon.title: some passages relating to the doomsday project (1984 - 1986)
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
the bbc doomsday project was a computerised survey of the nation undertaken to celebrate the 900th anniversary of the doomsday book
it was published on two laser disks with a graphical interface designed specificity for the project which has been replicated across multiple modern it packages.
sadly it now faces digital obsolescence as it only ran on one acorn computer and those are now rare. in addition copyright law has made the duplication of much of the content impossible as the project opened up content production to individuals rather than experts (another aspect of this project which has become the norm since) and the resultant need to get copyright clearance has rendered this vital and important historical document unacceptable to most people.
the first track's title comes from an entry for the area i live in now and the second one is based upon several entries for the area i grew up in.
the cover comes from a still image taken from the second 'community' disc.

elizabeth veldon.title: songs for the summer walker in the woods
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
'summer walkers' is a term given to indigenous highland travellers and this track came about after being told about one which slept each year in the woods near the home of someone i know
'Elizabeth Veldon’s ‘Songs For The Summer Walker In The Woods‘ has for nearly half of its 30 minute duration a gulf of silence before sparse clusters and single ringing piano notes amble into view. Occasionally more violentally struck gestures occur. An autumnal, chilly, still atmosphere pervades its length. Silence is a crucial component, the gaps between sounds over a track this long cause the listener to cling to the short periods of subtle instrumental work. ‘Songs For The Summer Walker In The Woods’ is a work of patience and calm with plenty of space for thought and reflection of your own. The music becomes at times a soft, welcome intrusion; dead leaves falling gracefully from a skeletal canopy.'
earsforeyes.co.uk/2017/09/08/music-from-the-woods-elizabeth-veldon-eastville-evp-jorge-boehringer-ailbhe-nic-oireachtaigh-queef-three-eyed-makara/

elizabeth veldon.title: star of the sea, pray for us sinners, pray for me
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this album was suggested by reading 'the flower of paradise' by david j. rothenberg
the first track is based upon the plain song ave maris stella and the later 'hail queen of heaven, the ocean star' by John Lingard (1771–1851) which was a part of my own upbringing and training in the local choir.
the third track is based on a 13th century anthon (first vespers, parBN Lat. 15182, fol. 304)
the use of discord throughout the three pieces owes much to marina warner's 'alone of all her sex: the myth and cult of the virgin mary' which discusses the use of the image of mary and the marian cult as a way of instilling behavioural patterns in catholic girls.
the cover image is of agnes sorel represented as the enthroned virgin by jean fouquet (c. 1450)

elizabeth veldon.title: ten shaker dances for mother ann lee and christian that he may dance (group 3)
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
if I when my wife is sleeping
and the baby and Kathleen
are sleeping
and the sun is a flame-white disc
in silken mists
above shining trees,—
if I in my north room
dance naked, grotesquely
before my mirror
waving my shirt round my head
and singing softly to myself:
“I am lonely, lonely.
I was born to be lonely,
I am best so!”
If I admire my arms, my face,
my shoulders, flanks, buttocks
against the yellow drawn shades,—
Who shall say I am not
the happy genius of my household?
william carlos williams
'Twenty minutes of it, a time period that anyone in need for some fine minimal ambient drone material would be very happy and pleased to find within their ears. The tone that the artist is giving its attention too is ringing like some kind of magic, a vibrant minimalism that felt to me like it’s a morning time that never ends. As if Elizabeth Veldon had captured the morning glory, cultivated it with her experimental ways and managed to repeat this favorable feeling of sound until the very end.
It made my ears twinkle from delight, sparkling in it’s hypnotic relaxing ways. I couldn’t tell if it was moving, or if it was stable; but I could definitely tell that I was enjoying it very much. This serene serenity audio-wise simply had something lovely over it, as if an angel had stopped time and space & kept it ‘pause’ at the very best moment of moments.
When out of the blue & completely unexpected some sentimental piano notes appeared I was in a full state of pure bliss. Elizabeth Veldon had not only captivated the music of the perfect moment in time, she also cultivated it into something much more beautiful than it already was. Surreal, serene and in all honesty; pretty beautiful.'
yeahiknowitsucks.wordpress.com/2017/09/20/elizabeth-veldon-ten-shaker-dances-for-mother-ann-lee-and-christian-that-he-may-dance-group-3/

elizabeth veldon.title: that when i waked i cried to dream again
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
Be not afeard. The isle is full of noises,
Sounds, and sweet airs, that give delight, and hurt not.
Sometimes a thousand twangling instruments
Will hum about mine ears, and sometime voices,
That if I then had waked after long sleep
Will make me sleep again; and then in dreaming
The clouds methought would open and show riches
Ready to drop upon me, that when I waked
I cried to dream again.
I'm sorry there has been such a long time between releases: between moving house, starting my teacher training and recently beginning my first placement i've simply not had any time (added to this was the fact that I didn't have broadband)
I recently helped teach act 2, scene 2 of the tempest to a class and i was reminded of the beautiful poetry of caliban's lines
images taken from orlando's performance in jarman's adaptation of the tempest

elizabeth veldon.title: The Body Of A Brazilian Transexual (for Suzanne Moore) and other works from 'black circle gender fuck'
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
recently the writer Suzanne Moore left the Guardian because hundreds of staff members wrote a letter questioning the tone the newspaper had taken on trans rights and pointing out that several trans women had resigned from the newspaper.
they pointed out that the newspaper was a toxic workplace and this, it seems, was too much for Suzanne Moore who resigned and wrote a piece claiming she was victimised by a letter which did not mention her by name. in this piece she spoke about the 'Body Of A Brazilian Transexual' incident from several years ago and openly lied about what happened.
at the time i responded to this by turning my now defunct label 'black circle records' over to trans voices under the sub series 'black circle gender fuck.' this release collects the work i produced regarding this incident. some of this is still available, some of it has been long out of print but it is all presented in an unedited format, exactly how it was released.
i have supplied the transcript of a twitter thread i wrote detailing her lies as part of the download as well as pictures of the physical releases for these items. i do not own many of these any longer as they have been archived by the british library and, as such, will outlive Moore's career.
this is part of a desire to archive and make available queer histories and to make visible and audible the invisible and silent. this does not represent my work as it stands now but this must not be forgoten.

elizabeth veldon.title: the clouds are walking in the hills
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
'Released last summer, The Clouds are Walking in the Hills is a solitary drone track. It appears as a minimalist tone cluster on the surface but across 30 minutes of close listening, the sound gradually shifts and modulates, much like the titular clouds. The ear notices a series of long droning notes climbing over each other mixed with a faster Doppler effect, like a giant Leslie speaker cabinet spinning ethereal messages to all. '
toneglow.substack.com/p/003-overlooked-albums-of-2019

elizabeth veldon.title: the daily visitations of the clatter
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this recording of the glasgow underground was so loud that it overloaded in several places and the sound is heavily distorted. rather than being a fault in the recording this captures traveling on the underground well.
the title refers to the stories of plague pits that where, according to 19th century urban legends, found between west street and shields road. 'the clatter' was a glowing orb that emerged from the tunnel walls, filling the entire tunnel with the sound of crashing metal. it is said that faces of the dead could be saw inside the fog, twisted in pain.
though there have been no reported sightings of the entity since 1897 the underground has caused concern with it's noise levels particularly for workers.

trackinfo.label: black circle records
trackinfo.credits: from the daily visitations of the clatter, released July 27, 2015

elizabeth veldon.title: the first tree in the greenwood, it was the holly
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
the title, tracks 2 and four are based upon 'the holly bears a berry', track one 'in the bleak midwinter', track 3 on 'the snow it melts the soonest'
track five and seven are based upon the carols that bear their names
track six is a improvisation
tracks 8 and 9 come from 'the trinity carol roll' the earliest source for english polyphonic carols and track ten is based upon henry the eighth's song of the same title.

trackinfo.title: towards winter (if i where a shepherd i would give a lamb)
trackinfo.label: black circle records
trackinfo.about:
in the bleak midwinter, frosty wind made moan,
earth stood hard as iron, water like a stone;
snow had fallen, snow on snow, snow on snow,
in the bleak midwinter, long ago.
our god, heaven cannot hold Him, nor earth sustain;
heaven and earth shall flee away when he comes to reign.
in the bleak midwinter a stable place sufficed
the lord god almighty, jesus christ.
enough for him, whom cherubim, worship night and day,
breastful of milk, and a mangerful of hay;
enough for Him, whom angels fall before,
the ox and ass and camel which adore.
angels and archangels may have gathered there,
cherubim and seraphim thronged the air;
but his mother only, in her maiden bliss,
worshipped the beloved with a kiss.
what can i give him, poor as I am?
if i were a shepherd, I would bring a lamb;
if i were a wise man, I would do my part;
yet what I can i give him: give my heart.
(text: christina rossetti)
trackinfo.credits: from the first tree in the greenwood, it was the holly, released December 2, 2013

and mary bore sweet jesus christ
to be our sweet saviour
o the rising of the sun
and the running of the deer
the playing of the merry organ
sweet singing of the choir
the holly bears a berry
as red as any blood
and mary bore sweet jesus christ
to do poor sinners good
o the rising of the sun
and the running of the deer
the playing of the merry organ
sweet singing of the choir
the holly bears a prickle
as sharp as any thorn;
and mary bore sweet jesus christ
on christmas day in the morn.
o the rising of the sun
and the running of the deer
the playing of the merry organ
sweet singing of the choir
the holly bears a bark
as bitter as any gall;
and mary bore sweet jesus christ
for to redeem us all.
o the rising of the sun
and the running of the deer
the playing of the merry organ
sweet singing of the choir
the holly and the ivy
now both are full well grown,
of all the trees that are in the wood,
the holly bears the crown.
o the rising of the sun
and the running of the deer
the playing of the merry organ
sweet singing of the choir

trackinfo.title: the cherry tree carol
trackinfo.label: black circle records
trackinfo.about:
JOSEPH was an old man
and an old man was he,
And he married Mary,
the Queen of Galilee.
When Joseph was married,
and Mary home had brought,
Mary proved with child,
and Joseph knew it not.
Joseph and Mary walked
through a garden gay,
Where the cherries they grew
upon every tree.
O then bespoke Mary,
with words both meek and mild:
‘O gather me cherries, Joseph,
they run so in my mind.’
And then replied Joseph,
with words so unkind:
‘Let him gather thee cherries
that got thee with child.’
O then bespoke our Saviour,
all in his mother’s womb:
‘Bow down, good cherry-tree,
to my mother’s hand.’
The uppermost sprig
bowed down to Mary’s knee:
‘Thus you may see, Joseph,
these cherries are for me.’
‘O eat your cherries, Mary,
O eat your cherries now;
O eat your cherries, Mary,
that grow upon the bough.’
As Joseph was a walking,
he heard an angel sing:
‘This night shall be born
our heavenly king.
‘He neither shall be born
in housen nor in hall,
Nor in the place of Paradise,
but in an ox’s stall.
‘He neither shall be clothed
in purple nor in pall,
But all in fair linen,
as were babies all.
‘He neither shall be rocked
in silver nor in gold,
But in a wooden cradle,
that rocks on the mould.
‘He neither shall be christened
in white wine nor red,
But with fair spring water,
with which we were christened.’
Then Mary took her young son,
and set him on her knee:
‘I pray thee now, dear child,
tell how this world shall be.’
‘O I shall be as dead, mother,
as the stones in the wall;
O the stones in the street, mother,
shall mourn for me all.
‘And upon a Wednesday
my vow I will make,
And upon Good Friday
my death I will take.
‘Upon Easter-day, mother,
my rising shall be;
O the sun and the moon
shall uprise with me.
’ The people shall rejoice,
and the birds they shall sing,
To see the uprising
of the heavenly king.’
trackinfo.credits: from the first tree in the greenwood, it was the holly, released December 2, 2013

trackinfo.title: there is no rose of swych vertu
trackinfo.label: black circle records
trackinfo.about:
Ther is no rose of swych vertu
As is the rose that bare Jhesu.
Alleluya.
Be that rose we may weel see
That he is God in personys thre,
Pari forma.
For in this rose conteynyd was
Heuen and erthe in lytyl space,
Res miranda.
The aungelys sungyn the shepherdes to:
‘Gloria in excelsis Deo’.
Gaudeamus.
Leue we all this wordly merthe,
And folwe we this joyful berthe;
Transeamus.
trackinfo.credits: from the first tree in the greenwood, it was the holly, released December 2, 2013

trackinfo.title: deo gracias anglia
trackinfo.label: black circle records
trackinfo.about:
Deo gratias Anglia redde pro victoria!
Owre Kynge went forth to Normandy
With grace and myght of chyvalry
Ther God for hym wrought mervelusly;
Wherefore Englonde may call and cry
Chorus
Deo gratias!
Deo gratias Anglia redde pro victoria!
He sette sege, forsothe to say,
To Harflu towne with ryal aray;
That toune he wan and made afray
That Fraunce shal rewe tyl domesday.
Chorus
Then went hym forth, owre king comely,
In Agincourt feld he faught manly;
Throw grace of God most marvelsuly,
He had both feld and victory.
Chorus
Ther lordys, erles and barone
Were slayne and taken and that full soon,
Ans summe were broght into Lundone
With joye and blisse and gret renone.
Chorus
Almighty God he keep owre kynge,
His peple, and alle his well-wyllynge,
And give them grace wythoute endyng;
Then may we call and savely syng:
Chorus
trackinfo.credits: from the first tree in the greenwood, it was the holly, released December 2, 2013

trackinfo.title: pastime with good company
trackinfo.label: black circle records
trackinfo.about:
Pastime with good company
I love and shall unto I die;
Grudge who list, but none deny,
So God be pleased thus live will I.
For my pastance
Hunt, song, and dance.
My heart is set:
All goodly sport
For my comfort,
Who shall me let?
Youth must have some dalliance,
Of good or illé some pastance;
Company methinks then best
All thoughts and fancies to dejest:
For idleness
Is chief mistress
Of vices all.
Then who can say
But mirth and play
Is best of all?
Company with honesty
Is virtue vices to flee:
Company is good and ill
But every man hath his free will.
The best ensue,
The worst eschew,
My mind shall be:
Virtue to use,
Vice to refuse,
Shall I use me.
trackinfo.credits: from the first tree in the greenwood, it was the holly, released December 2, 2013

elizabeth veldon.title: the fruit between my lips to clotted blood  was transubstantiate
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
THE MORNING BEFORE THE BATTLE
To-day, the fight : my end is very soon,
And sealed the warrant limiting my hours :
I knew it walking yesterday at noon
Down a deserted garden full of flowers.
. . Carelessly sang, pinned roses on my breast,
Reached for a cherry-bunch — and then, then, Death
Blew through the garden from the North and East
And blighted every beauty with chill breath.
I looked, and ah, my wraith before me stood,
His head all battered in by violent blows :
The fruit between my lips tO' clotted blood
Was transubstantiate, and the pale rose
Smelt sickly, till it seemed through a swift tear-flood
That dead men blossomed in the garden-close.
robert graves.
for the centenary of the somme.

elizabeth veldon.title: the house of god
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this album came about after the fire at notre dame and asks us to consider where 'the house of god' is situated.
the cover combines images of notre dame and the greenfell tower to create a single 'house of god.'
much of my thoughts on this are expressed in McCaig's 'Assisi'
The dwarf with his hands on backwards
sat, slumped like a half-filled sack
on tiny twisted legs from which
sawdust might run,
outside the three tiers of churches built
in honour of St Francis, brother
of the poor, talker with birds, over whom
he had the advantage
of not being dead yet.
A priest explained
how clever it was of Giotto
to make his frescoes tell stories
that would reveal to the illiterate the goodness
of God and the suffering
of His Son. I understood
the explanation and
the cleverness.
A rush of tourists, clucking contentedly,
fluttered after him as he scattered
the grain of the Word. It was they who had passed
the ruined temple outside, whose eyes
wept pus, whose back was higher
than his head, whose lopsided mouth
said Grazie in a voice as sweet
as a child’s when she speaks to her mother
or a bird’s when it spoke
to St Francis.
I have made this album free, i trust you will decide what the value two hours of music is worth to you and that you can donate this to whatever you consider a worthwhile cost.

elizabeth veldon.title: the limits of the known
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
the titles, structure and theme of this album where sugested by ‘antartica’ by j. gordon hayes (published in 1928 by the riverside press, london) which discusses the limits of exploration of antartica at that point and discusses the climate and topography of the contenent and possible routes for explorers to take in the future.
this album uses these ideas as a metaphor for the production of art as well as paying tribute to the people who explored this region.

elizabeth veldon.about:
this album concerns a train crash charles dickens experienced and which influenced the writing of 'the signalman'
it was said by those who knew him that after experiencing the crash in which many where killed he would have an anxiety attack when he was on a train and it swayed
this is a christmas album (sort of)

elizabeth veldon.title: the new year reviving old desires
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
the album title comes from the fitzgerald translation of 'the rubaiyat of omar khayyam':
Now the New Year reviving old Desires,
The thoughtful Soul to Solitude retires,
Where the White Hand Of Moses on the Bough
Puts out, and Jesus from the Ground suspires.
the title of track one is from jarman's 'blue':
The darkness comes in with the tide
The year slips on the calendar
Your kiss flares
A match struck in the night
Flares and dies
My slumber broken
Kiss me again
Kiss me
Kiss me again
And again
Never enough
Greedy lips
Speedwell eyes
Blue skies

trackinfo.credits: from the new year reviving old desires, released December 31, 2016

trackinfo.title: this year and on, a slow acumilation of ages

trackinfo.credits: from the new year reviving old desires, released December 31, 2016

elizabeth veldon.title: the new year reviving old desires
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
I have long been attracted to the Edwardian gloom of fitzgerald’s translation of omar khayyam and found myself muttering the fourth stanza to myself over and over again as the new year came in.
Now the New Year reviving old Desires,
The thoughtful Soul to Solitude retires,
Where the WHITE HAND OF MOSES on the Bough
Puts out, and Jesus from the Ground suspires.
happy new year

elizabeth veldon.title: the obscuring veil (and other metaphors for the state we are in)
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this is an album born of anger.
I asked Liv Radigue about their tracks and they gave this statement:
These are pieces of frustration and anger. I hope they don’t but I think the electorate will just swallow what they’re told and scares the shit out of me.
my pieces where recorded long before the election where called and relate to my experience of negotiating online spaces as a queer person. it was tempting to change the titles to reflect the political situation we are in but, well, fascism takes many forms and the gross disrespect of other's lived experiences may well be one.
there's still tim to register for the coming election if you live in the uk:  www.gov.uk/register-to-vote

elizabeth veldon.title: the protection of osiris against the violence of typho must be elicited according to the proper rites and sacrifices'
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
the title comes for this piece comes from anthanasius kircher's (1601/02-1680) erroneous (and spectacularly long) mistranslation of the cartouch containing the names of apries
regardless of these spectacular failures his work on the coptic language was vital in finally understanding hieroglyphs
the full 'translation' is:
The protection of Osiris against the violence of Typho must be elicited according to the proper rites and ceremonies by sacrifices and by appeal to the tutelary Genii of the triple world in order to ensure the enjoyment of the prosperity customarily given by the nile against the violence of the enemy Typho

elizabeth veldon.title: the recording angel of llangernyw yew
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this album refers to the llangernyw yew, a 5-6,000 year old yew standing in llangernyw church yard in wales.
local legend tells of the angelystor (recording angel) who each halloween foretells the names of all those in the village who will die that year.
one local man, Siôn Ap Rhobert, was said to have voiced his disbelief in the angelystor only to hear his own name called.

elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
the title and song titles are taken from 'the story of the jewish calender' by azriel eisenberg, published by abelard-schuman, 1958.
this was designed as a book for children to read to understand the jewish calendar. an understanding of the jewish calendar is necessary to determine the dates of several jewish festivals.
this album is dedicated to rhondalea who bought the book

elizabeth veldon.title: the toil of all that be helps not the primal fault
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
reading anthony avenue's 'star stories: constellations and people' i was reminded of housman's poem:
Stars, I have seen them fall,
But when they drop and die
No star is lost at all
From all the star-sown sky.
The toil of all that be
Helps not the primal fault;
It rains into the sea,
And still the sea is salt.
The cover features a nasa image of the pleads and a full size version of the image will be included in the download (i have retained the copy rite watermark on the image)

elizabeth veldon.title: the transport
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
the horrors of the holocaust can often leave us with a feeling of profound nihilism, an all-­‐encompassing hopelessness in the face of inhumanity.
In opposition to this stands the lonely figure of t.s. elliot working fire guard duty on the roof of faber and faber during the London blitz and	finding his love for other people growing, coming to the realisation that the world is full of beauty that needs to be preserved.
Against hate stands love:
‘Who then devised this torment? Love.’
track one uses samples from transacord recordings of steam trains, track two a recording of t.s. elliot reading the first verse of the lyric section of little gidding
The world turns and the world changes,
But one thing does not change.
In all of my years, one thing does not change,
However you disguise it, this thing does not change:
The perpetual struggle of Good and Evil.
-T. S. Eliot, Choruses from The Rock (1934)
download here:  buddhistonfire.com/2012/10/39-elizabeth-veldon---the-transport/
elizabeth veldon.credits:
released January 3, 2013
album cover: john tocher

elizabeth veldon.title: the unity of divinity and the world, the cardinal points, the four elements
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this album came about after a discussion of ancient symbols and relates to the cross.
the cross is one of the most ancient symbols in existence and dates back to the upper paleolithic and, as such, are as old as behaviourally modern humans. everything we are is tied up with the cross in one form or another and it could be said that, on one level, it defines modern humans.
seventy thousand years of use is some powerful magic.

elizabeth veldon.title: they have all gone into the world of light (for gladys)
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
This album is for a trans*women i met early in my own transition who has recently suffered two strokes.
the title refers to a poem with the same title by henry vaughan and the second track refers to the fates, three sisters who, in greek mythology, determined the lifes and fates of mortals. atropos, on of the sisters, ended the lifes of both mortals and gods by sniping the thread of life spun by clotho at a point predetermined by lachesis who drew lots at the beginning of a person's life to determine how long they would live.
the download includes the text of the poem and the representation of the fates from a flemish tapestry from ca 1520 used in the cover

elizabeth veldon.title: thornset orange berries cluster/ flamin’, beauty-fain.
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
Sea Buckthorn
Saut an’ cruel winds tae shear it,
Nichts o’ haar an’ rain –
Ye micht think the sallow buckthorn
Ne’er a hairst could hain;
But amang the sea-bleached branches
Ashen-grey as pain,
Thornset orange berries cluster
Flamin’, beauty-fain.
Daith an’ dule will stab ye surely,
Be ye man or wife,
Mony trauchles an’ mischances
In ilk weird are rife;
Bide the storm ye canna hinder,
Mindin’ through the strife,
Hoo the luntin’ lowe o’ beauty
Lichts the grey o’ life.
Helen Cruickshank

elizabeth veldon.title: three books of alchemy for anastasia in her grief
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this album discusses the act of grieving through the spiritual practices of alchemy.
rather than being a striving for riches alchemy was a spiritual process in which the act of spiritual cleansing is mirrored in the raising of base metals (such as lead) to gold (alchemists believed they where the same material) through the removal of the spiritual impurities in the base materials.
the colours in the artwork are the colours of the alchemical process - from black to white to yellow and finally red.
for for anastasia in her grief
this is a companion piece to 'all the rest have thirty one'

elizabeth veldon.title: three lowland songs
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
i'm working with two other artists to compile an album of tracks about the lowlands of scotland which are, more often than not, represented as cultural wastelands in much of scottish art (particularly in poetry)
these improvisations around three lowlands songs where recorded in one take on the 14th of january 2014.
i used a celviano ap-245 and a tascam dr-40.
the text of 'bleacher lassie o kelvinhaugh' i use has been borrowed from dick gaughan. his web site contains allot of lowlands songs and extensive notes and is highly recommended:  www.dickgaughan.co.uk/songs/index.html

elizabeth veldon.title: three monsters for halloween: the wendigo
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
the wendigo is a fascinating legend which is often presented in simplified forms for non native american audiences.
the legend of the wendigo is grounded in ideas of communitarianism verses individual greed and unchecked desire.
it's also utterly terrifying.

elizabeth veldon.title: three monsters for halloween: there are things in the hills and in the distance but we must not speak of them
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this album represents the final part of my trilogy of pieces for halloween that deal with elements of indigenous and marginalised cultures
this deals not with a monster or legend that has become part of culture but the lack of respect that we grant these cultures when we steal their heritage for a cheap thrill.
an example of this is the use of an indigenous myth exploited in the harry potter books without the permission of those who would be effected by it. I will not here discuss which creature this is as to do so is to invite speculation and questioning of indigenous people which they do not want.
we do not own other people's culture.
also: have fun this halloween.

elizabeth veldon.title: three monsters for halloween: zombie
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
in the haitian tradition (rather than the hollywood one) a zombie was a reanimated corpse sold into slavery and damned to exist in that state for ever.
in a related belief a zombie was forever stopped from being returned to the spiritual homeland of Africa (particularly Guinea) by Baron Samedi.
the removal of the shadow of slavery from the zombie legend in the american consciousness is, perhaps, rather telling.

trackinfo.label: black circle records
trackinfo.credits: from three monsters for halloween: zombie, released October 7, 2019

elizabeth veldon.title: three plague songs
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
one of the things you can do when working with folk song is to choose what version of a song you work with. here i have stripped out two verses from this song about two sisters who hid themselves away from the plague in perthshire only for the young man who loved one of them to infect them.
in my version i have chosen to focus on the mechanics of the story only and produce a text which, i think, is more abstracted.
the other tracks here spin off from this song.

elizabeth veldon.title: three school stories after rowling
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this album came about after a discussion of the use of the public school story form by j k rowling in the harry potter books.
i contend that this is, at heart, a reactionary form and share kipling's insight that it was implicated in the death toll of world war one as evidenced by his retelling of some of the stalky stories within the setting of books which explicitly discussed this event
there was a fault with my audio interface and this produced some unexpected sounds but i have chosen to keep these in the recording
these are the titles of each movement
1. 'there was not a penny to choose between any of them
for thoroughness, efficiency, and a certain clarity of outline that
stamps the work of the artist' [from 'the impressionists' by kipling]
2. 'and I must trouble you with an old man's wheezing waffle before we sink our teeth into our delicious feast. What a year it has been' [from 'harry potter and the sorcerer's stone' by j k rowling]
3. 'little I'd ever teach a son, but hitting,
shooting, war, hunting, all the arts of hurting.
well, that's what I learnt,—that, and making money
[from 'a terre' by wilfred owen]

trackinfo.title: three school stories after rowling
trackinfo.label: black circle records
trackinfo.credits: from three school stories after rowling, released August 8, 2016

elizabeth veldon.title: three solos in memory of cornelius cardew
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
'criticising bourgeois culture from within the system requires the critic to adopt some aspects of that system'
timothy d taylor 'moving in decency: the music and radical politics of cornelius cardew'
this piece has fallen out of my researches into autonomy and work within the artist/ audience relationship as cardew had, let us say, much to say on the subject of the political in music.
the first two tracks refer to 'the great learning' while the final refers to cardew's famous polemic 'stockhausen serves imperialism.'
this was recorded using the program 'sonic pi' on an inverness to edinburgh train and recorded directly from the program without an external interface.
this album is not to be taken as an endorsement of cardew's views or Maoism.
'progressive spirits working in the avantgarde find their way out, take a stand on the side of the people and set about making a positive contribution to the revolutionary movement.'
Cornelius Cardew.
the cover is a still from Philippe Regniez film on Cardew

elizabeth veldon.title: three songs for the dead (tenebrae responsories out of season for l)
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
taking the 'tenebrae responsoria' as a starting point (and in particular gesualdo's 'responsoria et alia ad officium hebdomadae sanctae spectantia') this lengthy work was prompted by a discussion of how we remember and pay respect to the dead but also how we continue with our own lives and how we cope with mental illness.
this is a journey from darkness to light.
The work is split into three sections that signify both the three days that the 'tenebrae responsoria' would be sung but also the three days between Christ's crucifixion and resurrection (any references to cage's 'a valentine out of season' are entirely intended.)
This is intended to be a single, three hour long piece but upload restrictions do not allow that
Sepulto Domino, signatum est monumentum,
Volventes lapidem ad ostium monumenti,
Ponentes milites qui custodirent illum.
Versus: Accedentes principes sacerdotum ad Pilatum, petierunt illum.
Gorczycki: In pace factus est locus eius, et in Sion habitatio eius.
Handl: Ne forte veniant discipuli eius, et furentur eum, et dicant plebi: surrexit ad mortuis.
Ponentes milites qui custodirent illum.
(The Lord being buried, the tomb was sealed
By rolling a stone across the door,
And soldiers were placed to guard it.
Versus: The chief priests went to Pilate and petitioned him.
Gorczycki: In peace is his place, and his dwelling is in Sion.
Handl: It may be that his disciples come and steal him away, and tell the people: he is risen from the dead.
And soldiers were placed to guard it.)

elizabeth veldon.title: three textures for imagined concrete surfaces
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this album came about after listening to/ watching two pieces by the composer Katrina Burton, particularly their piece for The Chapel of St. Albert's The Great
for me they capture the texture of that materials used within the spaces they compose for and i wished to capture this in a more abstract sense.
this imagines three concrete surfaces and tries to explore their textures and physicality.
the fact that Katrina Burton will be my supervisor for a piece of work this term had nothing to do with the making of these pieces.
honest.

elizabeth veldon.title: to describe a photograph (for cindy)
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this album was commissioned for the 'we need no swords' podcast.
it was written for a friend who is recovering from a serious illness and the first four tracks take extracts from sontag's writings on illness (which give my friend great solace) and set them for piano.
the fourth track is based on a photograph of the crowd at an early rolling stones gig that their mother attended; with the piece i try to imagine a photograph of their mother at the gig.
i have also included a sketch i made towards this final track (as well as the cover for the earlier release of this track) and my interview for this show which was cut to allow it to fit the show's format.
the podcast can be heard at:  www.mixcloud.com/pmargree/we-need-no-swords-episode-27-elizabeth-veldon/
sontag's writings where on cancer and it is cancer from which my friend is recovering. i had intended to make this a physical release to raise money for cancer care but instead have allowed it to be downloaded for free and ask you, as a listener, to contribute (if you can) to any charity you feel needs the money most

elizabeth veldon.title: to sit atop a pile of shattered rood screens
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this album was intended for release yesterday to commemorate the anniversary of luther's action which set in motion the reformation.
the title was suggested when a friend informed me that you could get rubber ducks with martin luther's face on them and i suggested that i would like to buy one to 'sit atop a pile of shattered rood screens'
this album is not intended as an anti-lutharian one but as a discussion of the darkness that followed the reformation and takes carl watkins' 'the undiscovered country: journeys among the dead' as a starting point for the impact of the reformation on congregations and the iconoclasm of the post-reformation period in britian as symptomatic of the religious violence of the period.
if you want to buy a martin luther rubber duck you can get them on ebay

elizabeth veldon.title: tom weir can not see the carved faces on the auld wife's lifts
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this track was originally part of the packaging for a release on herhalen and was available only with the physical copies.
tom weir was a hill walker, television presenter and writer who's television show 'weir's way' introduced a generation to the scottish landscape and scottish culture.
in his book 'tom weir's scotland' he discusses visiting the auld wife's lifts (a possible pre-christian worship site in baldernock parish) and not seeing the carved faces on the rock.
this was mastered from the only available copy which was an mp3 so the quality is a little off.

elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
today is the feast of the innocents, a commemoration of the children slaughtered under herod's command in the biblical story.
this album is about this year's innocents; all those killed in conflict, in violence, all those who have died through neglect and poverty.
“A voice was heard in Ramah,
Lamentation, weeping, and great mourning,
Rachel weeping for her children,
Refusing to be comforted,
Because they are no more."

elizabeth veldon.title: towards an abstract music
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
an attempt to produce a pure abstract music without reference to anything outside the music itself.
three rules where set for the production of the music:
1. no samples
2. no instruments
3. no titles which impart meaning

elizabeth veldon.title: two fens and a river path for tam (after vaughan williams)
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this is a return to producing a personal piece after a lengthy period of producing abstract and conceptual work.
this returns again (as i often have) to the feelings i still have for my brother who died suddenly when he was 37 and the time we lived together in cambridge.
the path in question goes along the cam near fed ditton where a caravan park we stayed for around a year in was situated. the path wasn't gone but was blocked off when i visited cambridge last.
for a more exact location it's around 52.22296865475131, 0.16704543165188912 on google maps

elizabeth veldon.title: two ghost stories
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
this year's halloween album is two ghost stories with live improvised piano acomplement.
the stories are my own experiencerience or perhaps they are not, their veracity is left to the listener to decide.
the piano is distorted and loud in this release, just so you know.
the second story is also quite dark and the whole release comes with cws:
drug use, psychosis, mental illness, homelessness and a sense of dread.
oh yea, the audio is a bit jump-scary (if that makes sense)
it strikes me, while mixing these for release, that the term 'my own true ghost story' may not register with most listeners. it belongs to one of kipling's 'indian' stories of the same title and can be found online.
blackwood's conversational tone when telling ghost stories can be experienced in this recording and may stand as a second little treat for halloween if you don't know his work:  www.youtube.com/watch?v=mCdX_hLo4kc
elizabeth veldon.credits:
released October 17, 2024
cover image comes from the university of sydney's victorian study group blog and is of the medium Stanislawa reabsorbing manifested ectoplasm (c1913)

elizabeth veldon.title: Two Hand Stencils
elizabeth veldon.label: black circle records
elizabeth veldon.about:
‘Two Hand Stencils’ is a two track album (both tracks are exactly 20 minutes) that explores, through a minimal style, the memory of forgotten ancestry. The incredibly prolific artist, elizabeth Veldon, releases a long-form drone album on Artapes Productions. Boldly doing what elizabeth does best – this is 40 minutes of sublime zero BPM. The album is streamable at the link above.
Elizabeth's multi layered drones are items of exquisite beauty and complexity. Whether lulling you into a calm bliss or haunting your waking dreams - you will find a lot to like about this album.
elizabeth veldon.credits:
released March 23, 2015
© Music: elizabeth Veldon
© Artwork: Paul Knowles
